Award.AwardTitle: Analytical Techniques for Studying On-Demand Shared-Use Mobility

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proliferation of smart mobile devices has given rise to on-demand economy, which aims to effectively bring together consumers and suppliers with very low transaction costs. As a typical example of on-demand economy, ride-sourcing companies, such as Uber and Lyft, are transforming the taxi industry and the way we travel in cities. The companies provide ride-hailing applications that intelligently source private car owners who drive their own vehicles to provide taxi services for profit to riders. These companies have been successful, but have created controversy. This controversy arises due to regulations in terms of price, entry and service quality that are imposed on the taxis while comparatively fewer regulatory requirements have been imposed on ride-sourcing companies. Unfair competition is argued particularly by cab drivers and their employers. The success of ride-sourcing services has thus created doubt about the efficacy of regulating the taxi industry; it challenges the very premise behind regulation in this industry. This grant will develop methodologies and tools for analyzing the structure and competition of taxi markets with ride-sourcing services and deriving insights on their regulation. The grant will provide timely support for the government agencies of many cities to better understand the impacts and implications of ride-sourcing companies and develop policies to guide their deployment. The research results can also shed light on the analysis and management of other types of on-demand economy and other emerging urban mobility services such as car sharing and ridesharing. This grant will involve students at all levels and traditionally underrepresented students, creating interactive, virtual environments for in-class use. Additionally, materials related to an on-demand economy and innovative urban mobility services will be developed to enhance existing courses.

The research will be conducted in two main thrusts. The first aims to develop an analytical framework to investigate optimal regulation regimes of a taxi market with ride-sourcing companies under simplified aggregate or macroscopic settings. Representing the matchings between customers and drivers by an exogenous matching function, the equilibrium properties of an aggregate taxi market will be examined under different market structures to derive insights on whether it is necessary or how to regulate the market. The aggregate model will be extended to network and dynamic contexts to better capture the spatial and temporal variability of the supply and demand of taxi services. The second thrust develops an agent-based simulation and a simulated test bed to provide a better understanding of the working mechanisms of ride-sourcing platforms, validate the analytical results obtained from developed models, and test various regulations and policies for more complex cases that are analytically intractable. If successful, this grant will advance the knowledge of and analysis capabilities for taxi markets. It will enrich the literature of transportation systems analysis, network modeling and agent-based simulation and modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The investigation of this project yielded a set of methodologies and tools to analyze ride-hailing markets with emerging ridesourcing services provided by companies like Uber and Lyft, and offered insights on the regulation of ridesourcing systems. In addition, we also conducted empirical studies on drivers's labor supply and examined the fundamental properties of ridesourcing systems, and developed strategies to support the operations of ridesourcing systems. 

The investigation has resulted in nine journal publications that appear in leading transportation journals such as Transportation Science, Transportation Research Part B and Part C, and another seven papers currently under review. The results have been further disseminated through a variety of media. These results formed the basis for two doctoral dissertations. The project also involved another two PhD students, providing them training on transportation modeling, economics, and operations research. The project will influence the education programs at University of Michigan and elsewhere by offering fresh materials and case studies to expand their curricula. The findings from this project provide timely support for the government agencies of many cities to better understand the impacts and implications of ridesourcing companies and develop policies to guide their deployment. The results can also help ridesourcing platforms improve their operation strategies such as matching, pricing and repositioning to achieve higher system throughput and fewer empty miles in their systems. The research results can also shed light on the analysis and management of other types of on-demand economy and other emerging urban mobility services such as car sharing and ridesharing.  

Specific research outcomes are summarized as follows.

Regulation. The regulation policy resulting from our investigation is commission regulation, i.e., cap the commission that a platform may collect from each transaction. This regulation is different from what has been implemented in practice and has great potential to enhance market efficiency. The policy can have different granularity levels. The cap may be imposed per trip, unit distance or time, and can vary with respect to location or even time of day. The choice will depend on the trade-off between implementation complexity and effectiveness. 

System analysis. We have investigated the supply function of a ridesourcing market under different service conditions. We discussed various causes for the supply curve to be backward bending and then proposed solutions for cases when inefficiencies arise. 

System modeling. We have developed a macroscopic fluid model to assist with strategic decision-makings of a platform for operating a large-scale ridesourcing system. The model captures the spatiotemporal dynamics of the system, and is flexible in representing control policies that a platform is implementing. 

Transportation planning. A new traffic assignment model has been developed to model the empty trips made by ridesourcing vehicles due to repositioning before matching or picking up a passenger after matching. The model describes the equilibrium state that results from the interactions between background regular traffic, and occupied, idle and deadheading ridesourcing vehicles.

Driver behaviors. We have investigated driver's labor supply and customer search behaviors. For the former, our results suggest that, when deciding whether to continue a shift, drivers pay more attention to future income opportunities and the time already spent working rather than their current earning level. For the latter, we modeled drivers' customer search as absorbing Markov decision processes and calibrated a dynamic discrete choice model. It is found that ridesourcing drivers do respond actively and positively to the repetitive market variations when idle.  Our results also suggest that idle drivers show a clear tendency of repositioning towards the faraway hotspots, especially during the evening with less demand in the suburb. 

Operation strategies. We have investigated four ideas to improve the operations of a ridesourcing system: 1) extending current matching algorithms by explicitly treating matching interval as a decision variable and then optimizing it real time. We applied reinforcement learning to derive policies for adaptive matching interval; 2) utilizing contract drivers to hedge against the risk of supply shortage at certain times of day. Contract drivers are those who receive fixed income and are required to work for a certain period of time. We investigated optimal contract design under dual sourcing and examined the impacts of dual sourcing on various stakeholders; 3) developing customer-focused heuristics for efficient, real-time matching for ridepooling. We proposed a restricted subgraph method and compared it with other existing heuristic and optimization-based matching algorithms; 4) exploring the conditions when to offer solo, pooling services or both of them.

Simulation. We have developed two simulation tools. The first captures how different regulation polices affect the performance of a ridesourcing market while the second aims to support the operations of a ridesourcing platform.
